channel.title: Get Started on Jenkins X
channel.description: Recent content in Get Started on Jenkins X

item.title: Get jx
item.description: Pick the most suitable instructions for your operating system: macOs On a Mac you can use brew: brew tap jenkins-x/jx brew install jx Or if you have not installed brew and prefer to install by hand: curl -L https://github.com/jenkins-x/jx/releases/download/v1.1.4/jx-darwin-amd64.tar.gz | tar xzv sudo mv jx /usr/local/bin Linux curl -L https://github.com/jenkins-x/jx/releases/download/v1.1.4/jx-linux-amd64.tar.gz | tar xzv sudo mv jx /usr/local/bin Other platforms download the binary for jx and add it to your $PATH

item.title: Create new Cluster
item.description: To create a new Kubernetes cluster with Jenkins X installed use the jx create cluster command: jx create cluster A number of different public cloud providers are supported as shown below. Here’s a little demo showing GKE, AKS and Minikube in parallel. It can take some time to start on different machines/clouds so please be patient! Using Google Cloud (GKE) Use the jx create cluster gke command:

item.title: Install on Kubernetes
item.description: To install Jenkins X on an existing kubernetes cluster use the jx install command: jx install

item.title: What's next?
item.description: OK so you have got the jx CLI and you either created a Kubernetes cluster with Jenkins X installed Jenkins X on an existing kubernetes cluster So whats next? Well the Developing section contains the next steps you may want to try out, such as create a new Spring Boot application and import it into Jenkins X create a new quickstart and import it into Jenkins X import existing source code into Jenkins X browsing for browsing pipelines, builds, apps and activity
